content.raw:
It was failing to link when I used ZeroMQ 4.2.2, so I tried using an older version 4.1.6, but this one is failing to `find_library`. One issue is that the library name depends on whether the Visual Studio IDE or nmake makefiles are used. I tried copying the libraries to match the expected filename, but I can't figure out how to get it to `find_library`

* https://github.com/zeromq/zeromq4-1/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L139-L143
* https://github.com/zeromq/zeromq4-1/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L614-L616
content.html:
It was failing to link when I used ZeroMQ 4.2.2, so I tried using an older version 4.1.6, but this one is failing to find_library. One issue is that the library name depends on whether the Visual Studio IDE or nmake makefiles are used. I tried copying the libraries to match the expected filename, but I can't figure out how to get it to find_library

  • https://github.com/zeromq/zeromq4-1/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L139-L143
  • https://github.com/zeromq/zeromq4-1/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L614-L616

content.raw: Confirmed. That works
content.html: Confirmed. That works

content.raw: Is it still producing the issue with failing to link to some Windows-specific functions, or has it moved past that?
content.html: Is it still producing the issue with failing to link to some Windows-specific functions, or has it moved past that?

update.description:
This branch was made by @caguero 

I haven't reviewed or tested it yet, but wanted to get the pull request process started.

This needs the following ign-cmake PR:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/17/find-modules-needed-for-ignition-transport/diff
update.title: Use ign-cmake

content.raw: Could you confirm with pull request #254?
content.html: Could you confirm with pull request #254?

content.raw: I think so. It works for me if I comment it out for now.
content.html: I think so. It works for me if I comment it out for now.

content.raw:
I think I found the issue in [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/efad1de04a1a0fbb49bb88f3b837235091329d96/tools/ign_TEST.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#ign_TEST.cc-337) line.

I added that line to prevent the following situation:

* You compiled and installed and old library version.
* You compile and NOT install the current version. You want your tests to link against the current version under `build` and not against the old library installed.
content.html:
I think I found the issue in this line.

I added that line to prevent the following situation:

  • You compiled and installed and old library version.
  • You compile and NOT install the current version. You want your tests to link against the current version under build and not against the old library installed.

content.raw: So that line overwrites our `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`, resulting the error?
content.html: So that line overwrites our LD_LIBRARY_PATH, resulting the error?

content.raw: I'm on the edge of my seat!
content.html: I'm on the edge of my seat!

content.raw: If I print the value of the environment variable `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` in the main () of `ign_TEST` shows the correct value. However, within `TEST(ignTest, TopicList)` the value is different.
content.html: If I print the value of the environment variable LD_LIBRARY_PATH in the main () of ign_TEST shows the correct value. However, within TEST(ignTest, TopicList) the value is different.

content.raw: My explanation to that question is that I didn't have libignition-math3 linked in libignition-transport4.so or `INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPublisher_aux`, so the linker didn't try to find them.
content.html: My explanation to that question is that I didn't have libignition-math3 linked in libignition-transport4.so or INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPublisher_aux, so the linker didn't try to find them.

content.raw: I guess that raises the question of why it was working for `ign-math3`+`ign-msgs0`? Is it possible that both of you have those libraries installed system-wide instead of relying on them being in `~/local/`?
content.html: I guess that raises the question of why it was working for ign-math3+ign-msgs0? Is it possible that both of you have those libraries installed system-wide instead of relying on them being in ~/local/?

content.raw:
Interesting discovery:

* I had `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` pointing to `/home/caguero/local/lib` . Result: didn't work.
* Alternatively, adding `/home/caguero/local/lib` to `/etc/ld.so.conf` and running `sudo ldconfig` make it work!

I thought these two alternatives were equivalent with the caveat that you need root access for the second alternative. I'm still confused.
content.html:
Interesting discovery:

  • I had LD_LIBRARY_PATH pointing to /home/caguero/local/lib . Result: didn't work.
  • Alternatively, adding /home/caguero/local/lib to /etc/ld.so.conf and running sudo ldconfig make it work!

I thought these two alternatives were equivalent with the caveat that you need root access for the second alternative. I'm still confused.

content.raw:
By the way, my error is slightly different than Nate's:


```
#!c++

/home/caguero/workspace/ign-transport/build/test/integration/INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPublisher_aux: error while loading shared libraries: libignition-math4.so.4: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```
content.html:
By the way, my error is slightly different than Nate's:

/home/caguero/workspace/ign-transport/build/test/integration/INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPublisher_aux: error while loading shared libraries: libignition-math4.so.4: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

content.raw: It does seem that those are the right environment variables to use for pointing at custom library directories on Linux, rather than plain `PATH`. I'm mixing up the Linux behavior with the Windows behavior which only has the `PATH` variable.
content.html: It does seem that those are the right environment variables to use for pointing at custom library directories on Linux, rather than plain PATH. I'm mixing up the Linux behavior with the Windows behavior which only has the PATH variable.

content.raw: With that combo (the one that works for us), I don't see libignition-math linked inside the `libignition-transport3.so` or `INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPublisher_aux`. However, `libignition-math4.so.4` is linked in `libignition-transport3.so` and `INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPublisher_aux` compiled with ign-cmake+msgs1+math4 .
content.html: With that combo (the one that works for us), I don't see libignition-math linked inside the libignition-transport3.so or INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPublisher_aux. However, libignition-math4.so.4 is linked in libignition-transport3.so and INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPublisher_aux compiled with ign-cmake+msgs1+math4 .

content.raw: Yeah, that does seem to be the case. I guess I don't know how `ign` hooks into the various ignition libraries, so I'll need to look more into that to understand why you'd be getting a failure to link to `libignition-msgs1`.
content.html: Yeah, that does seem to be the case. I guess I don't know how ign hooks into the various ignition libraries, so I'll need to look more into that to understand why you'd be getting a failure to link to libignition-msgs1.

content.raw: I have `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`, and `LIBRARY_PATH` pointing to `~/local/lib`.
content.html: I have LD_LIBRARY_PATH, and LIBRARY_PATH pointing to ~/local/lib.

content.raw: `PATH` is suppose to point to directories that contain executables, correct?
content.html: PATH is suppose to point to directories that contain executables, correct?

content.raw: math3  and msgs0 works for me.
content.html: math3 and msgs0 works for me.

content.raw: Dumb question, but is your `~/local/lib/` folder (that you're installing the libraries to) included in your `PATH` environment variable? If the `ign` binary is trying to link to `libignition-msgs1` at runtime, then it will likely fail if the library directory isn't in the `PATH`.
content.html: Dumb question, but is your ~/local/lib/ folder (that you're installing the libraries to) included in your PATH environment variable? If the ign binary is trying to link to libignition-msgs1 at runtime, then it will likely fail if the library directory isn't in the PATH.

content.raw:
I'll try that combo. I just cleaned, and the problem persists with math4, msgs1.

This error also exists on default, at least for me.
content.html:
I'll try that combo. I just cleaned, and the problem persists with math4, msgs1.

This error also exists on default, at least for me.

content.raw: I'm installing to `~local` too. I removed everything a couple of times. I'm on Zesty. Nate, does the msgs0+math3 combination work for you?
content.html: I'm installing to ~local too. I removed everything a couple of times. I'm on Zesty. Nate, does the msgs0+math3 combination work for you?

content.raw: I'm on Xenial, and I install everything to ~/local. I'll try wiping that, and retry.
content.html: I'm on Xenial, and I install everything to ~/local. I'll try wiping that, and retry.

content.raw: I've tried installing multiple major versions of `ign-math`, `ign-msgs`, and `ign-transport` side-by-side, but I haven't managed to recreate any test failures yet.
content.html: I've tried installing multiple major versions of ign-math, ign-msgs, and ign-transport side-by-side, but I haven't managed to recreate any test failures yet.

content.raw:
I see Nate's error in `default` right now. I've been debugging a little bit and I found the following:
  
  * Ign-transport (default) compiled with ign-cmake+ign-msgs1+ign-math4 -> Fail
  * ign-transport (default) compiled with ign-msgs0+ign-math3 -> Ok

Maybe @mxgrey  has any insight.
content.html:
I see Nate's error in default right now. I've been debugging a little bit and I found the following:

  • Ign-transport (default) compiled with ign-cmake+ign-msgs1+ign-math4 -> Fail
  • ign-transport (default) compiled with ign-msgs0+ign-math3 -> Ok

Maybe @mxgrey has any insight.

content.raw:
non-cov works too.

Combinations I've tried, no lib problems with any of them. I'm doing the default install to `/usr/local`

* ign-msgs1 + ign-math4
* ign-msgs default + ign-math default
* ign-msgs1 + ign-math default
content.html:
non-cov works too.

Combinations I've tried, no lib problems with any of them. I'm doing the default install to /usr/local

  • ign-msgs1 + ign-math4
  • ign-msgs default + ign-math default
  • ign-msgs1 + ign-math default

content.raw: That's a good question, it may affect the results. I should mention that locally I'm building the coverage build. Let me try non-coverage.
content.html: That's a good question, it may affect the results. I should mention that locally I'm building the coverage build. Let me try non-coverage.

content.raw: It looks like our `bitbucket-pipelines.yml` only performs `make test` on the `Coverage` build. Is that on purpose? Can we expect test successes/failures to be consistent between `Coverage` and the other build types?
content.html: It looks like our bitbucket-pipelines.yml only performs make test on the Coverage build. Is that on purpose? Can we expect test successes/failures to be consistent between Coverage and the other build types?

content.raw:
I've tried recreating these issues on my machine. Here's what I've tested so far:

- ign-transport (default) with ign-cmake+ign-msgs1+ign-math4 -> Ok
- ign-transport (ign-cmake) with ign-cmake+ign-msgs1+ign-math4 -> Ok
- ign-transport (default) with ign-msgs0+ign-math3 -> Ok (note: I uninstalled `ign-msgs1` to test this)

I haven't run into any failed tests. I made sure to have `ign-tools` default branch installed for all of these tests.

For people who are getting these errors: What is your build process like? Are you using catkin? Ament? Installing to the system? Do you have multiple major versions of `ign-math`, `ign-msgs`, or `ign-transport` installed?

I know I've run into test failures with `UNIT_ign_TEST` before, but I recall that it disappeared after doing a clean configure+build, and I haven't managed to recreate it since then.
content.html:
I've tried recreating these issues on my machine. Here's what I've tested so far:

  • ign-transport (default) with ign-cmake+ign-msgs1+ign-math4 -> Ok
  • ign-transport (ign-cmake) with ign-cmake+ign-msgs1+ign-math4 -> Ok
  • ign-transport (default) with ign-msgs0+ign-math3 -> Ok (note: I uninstalled ign-msgs1 to test this)

I haven't run into any failed tests. I made sure to have ign-tools default branch installed for all of these tests.

For people who are getting these errors: What is your build process like? Are you using catkin? Ament? Installing to the system? Do you have multiple major versions of ign-math, ign-msgs, or ign-transport installed?

I know I've run into test failures with UNIT_ign_TEST before, but I recall that it disappeared after doing a clean configure+build, and I haven't managed to recreate it since then.

content.raw: I just added `ign-tools` to pipelines and the test passes there too
content.html: I just added ign-tools to pipelines and the test passes there too
